Select an ecosystem from the map by clicking on it. Then explore the flora and fauna in the picture to learn more about them.

This rugged terrain occupies 70% of the nation. Although the mountains are not generally high, they can be extremely steep.
Manchurian Walnut (Juglans mandshurica) This hardy tree produces a nut with an edible kernel. The roots are used as a folk medicine to treat cancer.
Korean Ash (Fraxinus rhynchophylla) Wood products are made from the hardwood of this tree. The bark is used in folk medicine to treat diarrhea and painful, swollen eyes.
Brown Bear (Ursus arctos) These large bears generally avoid humans but may attack if surprised or threatened.
Oriental Firebelly Toad (Bombina orientalis) The toxins secreted through the toad’s skin are not usually dangerous to humans but can cause discomfort if ingested or absorbed through cuts.
Korean Rat Snake (Elaphe schrenckii) This is the largest indigenous snake on the Korean Peninsula. Although it is protected in South Korea, it is often killed for pharmaceutical use.
White-Bellied Black Woodpecker (Dryocopus javensis richardsi) This native bird has been designated as Natural Monument No. 197 in Korea, meaning it is granted special government protection.
Hackberry (Prunus padas) This bitter seed contains cyanide, which in small quantities stimulates respiration. Mixtures made from the bark are used to treat colds and sore throats.
/*2*/ Long cold winters with temperatures below freezing give way to monsoons during the summer.
Asian Black Bear (Ursus thibetanus) Called the moon bear, this white-chested species can be aggressive. It is categorized as Vulnerable because of habitat loss and hunting for gall bladders and skins.
Central Asian Pit Viper (Gloydius Intermedius) Measuring up to 76 cm (30 in), this snake’s bite releases a venom that attacks the nervous and cardiovascular systems.
Chinese Egret (Egretta eluphotes Classified as Vulnerable, this bird lives along shallow tidal estuaries and mudflats. It is highly valued for its beautiful plumage.
Chinese Goral (Naemorhedus caudatus) Resembling a goat, this animal is now listed as Vulnerable. It lives in herds in high mountain ranges and has few natural predators.
Chinese Softshell Turtle (Pelodiscus sinensis) Listed as Vulnerable, the meat of this turtle is a common soup ingredient.
Korean Pine (Pinus koraiensis) This large tree grows in the mountain areas, and its seeds are harvested and sold as pine nuts.
Maidenhair Fern (Adiantum pedatum) Tea made from this plant is good for treating coughs and congestion from colds, asthma, and fever.

In the summers this area is warm, wet, and humid. Winters are generally cool and dry.
Mochi Tree (Ilex integra) A member of the holly family, the young leaves of this tree can be cooked and eaten, although the fruits and seeds can be toxic.
Eurasian Curlew (Numenius arquata) This large wading bird feeds on small invertebrates, crabs, or earthworms found in mudflats. It is categorized as Near Threatened.
Hooded Crane (Grus monacha) This crane spends winters in South Korea. It is categorized as Vulnerable because of degradation of the wetland bogs where the birds feed and nest.
Wild Boar (Sus scrofa) Dangerous and aggressive when threatened, this wild boar can weigh as much as 90 kg (200 lbs).
Japanese Camellia (Camellia japonica) Tea oil from this flowering shrub is used as a sweet seasoning and cooking oil. The large red, pink, or white flowers are highly prized.
Camphor Tree (Cinnamomum camphora) This large flowering tree produces a compound called camphor, which can be used as a cooking spice or an insect repellent. It also repels fleas.
